sen.j: 鈴木氏（すずきし）日本の代表的姓氏のひとつ。
sen.e: The Suzuki clan was one of the representing seishi (hereditary family name) in Japan.
sen.cmt: 姓氏→定訳不明：seishi (hereditary family name) としました。
sen.e: The Suzuki clan is one of the representing seishi (hereditary family name) in Japan.
sen.cmt: was→is と修正しました。
sen.e: The Suzuki clan is one of the representing seishi (hereditary family name) in Japan.
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: かつての武家である鈴木氏との関係は諸説あって定まらないが、祭礼の際に祭られる稲穂に由来した神官の姓氏と考えられる。
sen.e: Although the relationship with a samurai family called the Suzuki clan is not clear because there are diversified theories on it, this seishi (hereditary family name) is thought to be of the Shinto priest and its origin derived from the rice ear used at the rituals.

Although the connection with the Suzuki clan who was once a samurai family, is not clear, since there are diversified theories on it, this seishi (hereditary family name) is thought to be of the Shinto priest and its origin derived from the rice ear used at the rituals.
sen.cmt: relationship→connection,「かつての武家である鈴木氏」、because→since と修正しました。カンマを補いました。
sen.e: Although the connection with the Suzuki clan who was once a samurai family, is not clear, since there are diversified theories on it, this seishi (hereditary family name) is thought to be of the Shinto priest and its origin derived from the rice ear used at the rituals.
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: 鈴木を名字とする家の多くは穂積氏を本姓としており、熊野三山信仰と関係が深い。
sen.e: The honsei (authentic surname) of many families whose family name is Suzuki is 'Hozumi,' and it is closely connected with belief in Kumano Sanzan (three major shrines in Kumano, Kumano-Hongu-Taisha Shrine, Kunamo-Hayatama-Taisha Shrine, and Kumano-Nachi-Taisha Shrine).
sen.cmt: 本姓→定訳不明：honsei (authentic surname) としました。 穂積氏→'Hozumi'としました。 熊野三山信仰→定訳不明：belief in Kumano Sanzan (three major shrines in Kumano, Kumano-Hongu-Taisha Shrine, Kunamo-Hayatama-Taisha Shrine, and Kumano-Nachi-Taisha Shrine)としました。
sen.e: The honsei (original name) of many families whose family name is Suzuki is 'Hozumi,' and it is deeply connected with the belief in Kumano Sanzan (three major shrines in Kumano, Kumano-Hongu-Taisha Shrine, Kunamo-Hayatama-Taisha Shrine, and Kumano-Nachi-Taisha Shrine).
sen.cmt: 「本姓」をウェブ上で確認すると"original name"というものが幾つかあり、そのように修正しました。closely→deeply と修正しました。the を補いました。
sen.e: Many families with their family name Suzuki has 'Hozumi' as the clan's original surname, and it is deeply connected with the belief in Kumano Sanzan (three major shrines in Kumano, Kumano-Hongu-Taisha Shrine, Kunamo-Hayatama-Taisha Shrine, and Kumano-Nachi-Taisha Shrine).
sen.cmt: 本姓をThe clan's original surnameとして変更しました。

sen.j: 穂積姓鈴木氏は熊野新宮の出身で、神官を受け継ぐ家系である。
sen.e: The Suzuki clan with the honsei (authentic surname) of Hozumi was originally from Kumano Shingu and this family line had handed down the post of Shinto priest.
sen.cmt: 穂積姓鈴木氏→定訳不明：the Suzuki clan with the honsei (authentic surname) of Hozumi としました。

sen.cmt: カッコ内を修正しました。カンマを補いました。
sen.e: The Suzuki clan with the honsei (original name) of Hozumi was originally from Kumano Shingu, and this family line had handed down the post of Shinto priest.
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: 鈴木氏は熊野神社の勧進や熊野を基地とする太平洋側の海上交通に乗って全国的に神官として分散した。
sen.e: The members of the Suzuki clan extended all over Japan, through kanjin (missionary activities) of Kumano-jinja Shrine and the maritime traffic in the Pacific Ocean side with Kumano as its basis.
sen.cmt: 勧進→定訳不明：kanjin (missionary activities)としました。
sen.e: The members of the Suzuki clan extended all over Japan as Shinto priests, through the kanjin (solicitation campaigns) of Kumano-jinja Shrine, and using the maritime traffic on the Pacific Ocean side with Kumano as its base,
sen.cmt: ここでの「勧進」は"kanjin (solicitation campaigns)"として修正しました。 「神官として」を補いました。後半部分を文脈より修正しました。
sen.e: The members of the Suzuki clan extended all over Japan as Shinto priests, through the kanjin (solicitation campaigns) of Kumano-jinja Shrine, and using the maritime traffic on the Pacific Ocean side with Kumano as its base,
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: また穂積姓の子孫ではなくても当時苗字を持つことを許されていた武家、源氏や平氏などの中で、信仰心の深い武家には神姓である鈴木姓を与えてきた故、鈴木の名字は瞬く間に東日本を中心に全国に広まったとされる。
sen.e: It is also said that, in addition to the descendents of the families whose honsei (authentic surname) was Hozumi, there were many samurai families which were given the family name 'Suzuki' for their devoted religious practices, and in this way, the myoji (family name) of Suzuki quickly extended in the eastern Japan and other regions of Japan.
sen.cmt: 鈴木姓→family name 'Suzuki' としました。 名字→myoji (family name)としました。
sen.e: It is also said that, in addition to the descendents of the families whose honsei (original name) was Hozumi, there were many samurai families which were given the family name 'Suzuki' for their devoted religious practices among those families who were allowed to have myoji (family name) at that time such as the Minamoto clan and the Taira clan, and in this way, the myoji (family name) of Suzuki quickly extended in the eastern Japan and other regions of Japan.
sen.cmt: authentic surname→original name と修正しました。「当時苗字を持つことを許されていた武家、源氏や平氏などの中で」の部分を補いました。
sen.e: It is also said that, in addition to the descendents of the families whose honsei (original name) was Hozumi, there were many samurai families which were given the family name 'Suzuki' for their devoted religious practices among those families who were allowed to have myoji (family name) at that time such as the Minamoto clan and the Taira clan, and in this way, the myoji (family name) of Suzuki quickly extended in the eastern Japan and other regions of Japan.
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: そのため鈴木姓のほとんどが、神姓穂積姓または源姓・平姓を含む武家の子孫と考えられる。
sen.e: Thus, almost of all the Suzuki families are considered to be descendents of the families which were using the Shinto-related honsei (authentic surname) of Hozumi or of the samurai families including those of Minamoto clan or Taira clan.
sen.cmt: 神姓穂積姓→定訳不明：Shinto-related honsei (authentic surname) of Hozumi としました。
sen.e: Thus, almost of all the Suzuki families are considered to be the descendents of the families, which were using the Shinto-related honsei (original name) of Hozumi or of the samurai families, including those of the Minamoto clan or the Taira clan.
sen.cmt: the, カンマを補いました。カッコ内を修正しました。「神姓穂積姓」の訳は確認が取れておりません。

sen.cmt: 修正なし

tit.cmt: 藤白鈴木氏→Fujishiro Suzuki clanとしました。

sen.j: 紀伊国藤白（現在の和歌山県海南市）の鈴木氏は、12世紀頃に熊野から同じ紀伊国内の藤白に移り住んで以来、王子社（現在の藤白神社）の神官を代々務めた家である。
sen.e: The Suzuki clan in Fujishiro, Kii Province (present Kainan City, Wakayama Prefecture) was the family of Shinto priest at Oji-sha Shrine (present Fujishiro-jinja Shrine)during generations, since it was transferred within the same Kii Province from Kumano to Fujishiro around 12th century.
sen.cmt: 紀伊国藤白→Fujishiro, Kii Provinceとしました。
sen.e: The Suzuki clan in Fujishiro, Kii Province (present Kainan City, Wakayama Prefecture) was the family of Shinto priests at Oji-sha Shrine (present Fujishiro-jinja Shrine) during the generations, since the family moved within the same Kii Province from Kumano to Fujishiro around 12th century.
sen.cmt: スペースを修正しました。the を補いました。priest→priests,it was transferred→the family moved と修正しました。
sen.e: The Suzuki clan in Fujishiro, Kii Province (present Kainan City, Wakayama Prefecture) was the family of Shinto priests at Oji-sha Shrine (present Fujishiro-jinja Shrine) during the generations, since the family moved within the same Kii Province from Kumano to Fujishiro around 12th century.
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: 全国に散らばる穂積姓鈴木氏中でも本家筋とみなされている家で、後述する雑賀衆の鈴木氏も三河国の鈴木氏もいずれも藤白の鈴木氏の分家とされている。
sen.e: It is said that the Suzuki clan of Saigashu (a Buddhist sect, Ikko groups) as well as the Suzuki clan of Mikawa Province (discussed later) were regarded as the head lines among the families of Suzuki clans of with the honsei (authentic surname) of Hozumi scattered all over Japan, and they were the branches of the Suzuki clan in Fujishiro.
sen.cmt: 雑賀衆→Saigashu (a Buddhist sect, Ikko groups) としました。 穂積姓鈴木氏→定訳不明：Suzuki clans of with the honsei (authentic surname) of Hozumiとしました。
sen.e: It is said that, these families discussed later including the Suzuki clan of Saigashu (a Buddhist sect, Ikko groups) as well as the Suzuki clan of Mikawa Province, were regarded as the head lines among the families of Suzuki clans of with the honsei (original name) of the Hozumi scattered all over Japan, and they were the branches of the Suzuki clan in Fujishiro.
sen.cmt: 文前半をよりスムースに修正しました。authentic surname→original name と修正しました。the, カンマを補いました。
sen.e: It is said that, these families discussed later including the Suzuki clan of Saigashu (a Buddhist sect, Ikko groups) as well as the Suzuki clan of Mikawa Province, were regarded as the head lines among the families of Suzuki clans of with the honsei (original name) of the Hozumi scattered all over Japan, and they were the branches of the Suzuki clan in Fujishiro.

sen.j: 平安時代の末に藤白鈴木氏から出た鈴木重家・亀井重清の兄弟は、源義経に郎党として仕え、陸奥国衣川 (岩手県)で主君を守って戦死した。
sen.e: At the end of the Heian Period, Shigeie SUZUKI and his brother Shigekiyo KAMEI, who were from the Fujishiro Suzuki clan and served MINAMOTO no Yoshitsune as roto (a retainer), died in battle in Koromogawa, Mutsu Province (Iwate Prefecture), protecting their master, Yoshitsune.
sen.cmt: 鈴木重家・亀井重清の兄弟→Shigeie SUZUKI and his brother Shigekiyo KAMEIとしました。 主君→their master, Yoshitsuneとしました。
sen.e: At the end of the Heian period, Shigeie SUZUKI and his brother Shigekiyo KAMEI, who were from the Fujishiro Suzuki clan and served MINAMOTO no Yoshitsune as roto (a retainer), died in a battle in Koromogawa, Mutsu Province (Iwate Prefecture), protecting their master, Yoshitsune.
sen.cmt: Period→period と修正しました。a を補いました。
sen.e: At the end of the Heian period, Shigeie SUZUKI and his brother Shigekiyo KAMEI, who were from the Fujishiro Suzuki clan and served MINAMOTO no Yoshitsune as roto (a retainer), died in a battle in Koromogawa, Mutsu Province (Iwate Prefecture), protecting their master, Yoshitsune.

sen.j: このため、藤白鈴木氏が全国の鈴木氏の本家筋と見られたのも東日本で鈴木姓が爆発的に広がったのも、中世日本社会で広く見られた義経人気にあやかったものとみる向きもある。
sen.e: Therefore, there is a theory that presumes the reasons why the Fujishiro Suzuki clan was deemed as the head line of the Suzuki families of all over Japan and why the family name 'Suzuki' had extended in eastern Japan at an explosive pace, and concludes that those happened because of a booming popularity of Yoshitsune generated in Japanese medieval society.

sen.cmt: 文脈よりスムースに修正しました。

sen.j: 鈴木重家の子が伊予国土居氏の祖となったという伝承があり、この説によると『清良記』の著者の土居清良は藤白鈴木氏の末裔ということになる。
sen.e: There is an oral tradition that Shigeie SUZUKI's son was the ancestor of the Doi clan of Iyo Province, and according to it, Kiyoyoshi DOI, the author of "Seiryoki" (The Record of Kiyoyoshi DOI) was Fujishiro Suzuki's descendent.

There is a tradition that Shigeie SUZUKI's son was the ancestor of the Doi clan of Iyo Province, and according to it, Kiyoyoshi DOI, the author of "Seiryoki" (The Record of Kiyoyoshi DOI) was a descendent of the Fujishiro Suzuki clan.
sen.cmt: an oral tradition→a tradition,Fujishiro Suzuki's descendent→a descendent of the Fujishiro Suzuki clan と修正しました。
sen.e: There is a tradition that Shigeie SUZUKI's son was the ancestor of the Doi clan of Iyo Province, and according to it, Kiyoyoshi DOI, the author of "Seiryoki" (The Record of Kiyoyoshi DOI) was a descendent of the Fujishiro Suzuki clan.

sen.j: 藤白鈴木氏は、1942年に第122代の当主が病気で急死し、子がいなかったため断絶した。
sen.e: The 122nd head of the Fujishiro Suzuki clan died suddenly from illness in 1942, and as he had no heir, the clan was extinguished.
The 122nd head of the Fujishiro Suzuki clan died suddenly from illness in 1942, and the clan was extinguished since he had no heir,

sen.j: 雑賀衆の鈴木氏は、戦国時代 (日本)に紀伊国十ヶ郷（現在の和歌山市西北部、紀の川河口付近北岸）の平井（和歌山市平井）あたりを本拠地としていた土豪。
sen.e: The Suzuki clan of Saigashu (a Buddhist sect, Ikko groups) was a local clan, which had its home base situated around the area of Hirai (Hirai, Wakayama City) of Kiinokuni-Jukkago (present northwest part of Wakayama City, the north shore around the river mouth of Kinokawa River) during the Sengoku Period (period of warring states).

The Suzuki clan of Saigashu (a Buddhist sect, Ikko groups) was a local clan, which had its home base situated around the area of Hirai (present Hirai, Wakayama City) of Jikkago, Kii Province (present northwest part of Wakayama City, the north shore around the river mouth of Kino-kawa River) during the Sengoku Period (Period of Warring States).
sen.cmt: present を補いました。Kiinokuni→Kii Province,Jukkago→Jikkago (用語集、ウェブ上共に確認しました） Kinokawa→Kino-kawa,「戦国時代」のカッコ部分を修正しました。

sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: 鈴木氏は紀ノ川対岸の雑賀荘（現在の和歌山市街周辺）を中心に周辺の荘園の土豪たちが結集してつくっていた雑賀衆の有力な家系のひとつで、十ヶ郷の指導者的な立場にあった。
sen.e: The Suzuki clan was one of the powerful family lines of Saigashu formed by the local clans settled in Saiga-so estate (present periphery of the urban area of Wakayama City) and those settled in its vicinity, and it was in the position of the leader of the Jukkago area.
sen.cmt: 雑賀荘→Saiga-so estate (present periphery of the urban area of Wakayama City) としました。
sen.e: The Suzuki clan was one of the powerful family lines of Saigashu, formed centering the Saiga-so estate (present periphery of the urban area of Wakayama City) by the local clans of the shoen (manor in medieval Japan) in the vicinity of, and it was in the position of the leader of the Jikkago area.
sen.cmt: 文脈より修正しました。Jukkago→Jikkago と修正しました。
sen.e: The Suzuki clan was one of the powerful family lines of Saigashu, formed centering the Saiga-so estate (present periphery of the urban area of Wakayama City) by the local clans of the shoen (manor in medieval Japan) in the vicinity of, and it was in the position of the leader of the Jikkago area.
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: 江戸時代の記録から、鈴木重意（重意）という人物が雑賀城主として数万石を領していたという話がよく取り沙汰されるが、実際に鈴木氏が居住していた十ヶ郷は雑賀城のある雑賀荘からみて川の対岸であり、信ずるに足りない。
sen.e: In the documents recorded in the Edo Period, a person called Shigeoki SUZUKI (or simply 'Shigeoki') frequently appears as the lord of Saiga-jo Castle with a stipend of several tens of thousands-koku of crop yield, however, in reality Jukkago, the place where the Suzuki clan was settled, was on the opposite shore of the Saiga-so estate, and these descriptions lack the credibility.

sen.cmt: recorded in→of,Period→period,thousands-koku→thousands koku,Jukkago→Jikkago,「実際に鈴木氏が居住していた十ヶ郷」の部分を修正しました。
sen.e: In the documents of the Edo period, a person called Shigeoki SUZUKI (or simply 'Shigeoki') frequently appears as the lord of Saiga-jo Castle with a stipend of several tens of thousands koku of crop yield, however, the Jikkago, where the Suzuki clan was actually settled, was on the opposite shore of the Saiga-so estate, and these descriptions lack the credibility.
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: 雑賀党の鈴木氏が本格的に歴史にあらわれるのは「雑賀孫市」の通称で知られる鈴木孫一が活躍した16世紀の中頃以降である。
sen.e: The Suzuki clan of Saigato came to be mentioned frequently in the history since mid-16th century, when Magoichi SUZUKI, commonly known as 'Magoichi SAIGA' worked actively.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処。
sen.e: The Suzuki clan of Saigato came to be mentioned frequently in history as from the mid-16th century, when Magoichi SUZUKI, commonly known as 'Magoichi SAIGA' took an active role.
sen.cmt: the を削除しました。since→as from the,worked actively→took an active role と修正しました。
sen.e: The Suzuki clan of Saigato came to be mentioned frequently in history as from the mid-16th century, when Magoichi SUZUKI, commonly known as 'Magoichi SAIGA' took an active role.
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: 雑賀衆のほかの土豪たちと同様、鉄砲伝来から間もない早い時期に鉄砲を使った戦術を取り入れ、16世紀の半ばには鉄砲で武装したある程度の規模の傭兵的集団として活動していたようである。
sen.e: It is probable that like other local clans of Saigashu, the clan introduced guns in its fighting tactics shortly after the arrival of guns to Japan, and by the mid-16th century the clan seems to have been active as a certain sized mercenary force equipped with guns.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処。
sen.e: Same as the other local clans of Saigashu, the clan adopted guns in its fighting tactics shortly after the arrival of guns to Japan, and by the mid-16th century the clan seems to have been active as a certain sized mercenary force equipped with guns.
sen.cmt: 前半をスムースに修正しました。introduced→adopted と修正しました。
sen.e: Same as the other local clans of Saigashu, the clan adopted guns in its fighting tactics shortly after the arrival of guns to Japan, and by the mid-16th century the clan seems to have been active as a certain sized mercenary force equipped with guns.
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: 1570年に織田信長が大阪の石山本願寺と開戦して石山戦争が起こると、鈴木孫一の率いる鈴木党は、他の雑賀衆の集団とともに本願寺の門主顕如の求めに応じて本願寺に入り、織田軍と戦った。
sen.e: In 1570, when Nobunaga ODA opened hostilities against Ishiyama Hongan-ji Temple and the Ishiyama War broke out, the Suzuki-to (group of Suzuki clan) lead by Magoichi SUZUKI fought against the Oda army, in response to the request of Kennyo, the head of Hongan-ji Temple, soliciting the participation to other Saigashu group.

In 1570, when Nobunaga ODA opened hostilities against Ishiyama Hongan-ji Temple and the Ishiyama War broke out, the Suzuki-to (group of Suzuki clan) lead by Magoichi SUZUKI, with the other groups of Saigashu, entering the Hongan-ji Temple as answering the request of Kennyo, the head of Hongan-ji Temple, fought against the Oda army.
sen.cmt: 文脈より修正しました。
sen.e: In 1570, when Nobunaga ODA opened hostilities against Ishiyama Hongan-ji Temple and the Ishiyama War broke out, the Suzuki-to (group of Suzuki clan) lead by Magoichi SUZUKI, with the other groups of Saigashu, entering the Hongan-ji Temple as answering the request of Kennyo, the head of Hongan-ji Temple, fought against the Oda army.
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: 鈴木孫一は石山本願寺に篭った雑賀衆の中でも最有力の頭目のひとりで、孫一自身も本願寺の門徒でもあったので本願寺にきわめて信頼された。
sen.e: Magoichi SUZUKI was one of the most powerful leaders of Saigashu that barricaded themselves inside Ishiyama Hongan-ji Temple, and as Magoichi himself was a follower of Hongan-ji Temple, he was greatly trusted by Hongan-ji Temple.

Magoichi SUZUKI was one of the most powerful leaders in the Saigashu that barricaded themselves inside of the Ishiyama Hongan-ji Temple, and as Magoichi himself was a follower of Hongan-ji Temple, he was extremely trusted by Hongan-ji Temple.

sen.e: Magoichi SUZUKI was one of the most powerful leaders in the Saigashu that barricaded themselves inside of the Ishiyama Hongan-ji Temple, and as Magoichi himself was a follower of Hongan-ji Temple, he was extremely trusted by Hongan-ji Temple.
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: しかし、1577年に本拠地の雑賀が織田軍の侵攻を受けると、紀ノ川北岸にあった鈴木氏の所領は真っ先に攻撃を受けて占領され、紀ノ川南岸での戦いも劣勢であったために鈴木氏は他の有力者たちとともに織田氏への服属を誓って降伏した。
sen.e: However, in 1577 when the group's home base, Saiga was attacked by the Oda army, the Suzuki clan's estate, which was on the north shore of Kinokawa River, became the first target to be attacked and occupied, and the Saiga forces were also on the backfoot at the fight on the south shore of Kinokawa River, the Suzuki clan, together with other influential local lords, surrendered to the Oda clan, pledging its submission.

sen.j: しかし、翌年には織田氏への服属を反故にし、再び本願寺に荷担した。
sen.e: However, the next year, the Suzuki clan withdrew the pledge of submission to the Oda clan, and once again it supported Hongan-ji Temple.

sen.j: 1580年、顕如が最終的に抗戦を断念し、石山本願寺を退去して雑賀の鷺森に移ると鈴木氏もこれに従い、織田氏に服属する。
sen.e: In 1580 when Kennyo, who definitely gave up the resistance, left Ishiyama Hongan-ji Temple and moved to Saginomori in Saiga, the Suzuki clan followed Kennyo and submitted to the Oda clan.

sen.j: これ以降、力を失った本願寺に代わって織田氏に服属しようとする鈴木氏と、それに反対する反織田派との間で争いが起こり、鈴木孫一は1582年に土橋氏の当主を殺害、雑賀衆の主導権を握った。
sen.e: Then, within Saigato, a confrontation arose between the group that insisted the submission to the Oda clan, instead of supporting Hongan-ji Temple which had lost its influence, and the group that was opposed to it, but after Magoichi SUZUKI killed the head of the Tsuchihashi clan in 1582, the Suzuki clan gripped the leadership of Saigashu.

Then, within Saigato, a confrontation arose between the group that insisted the submission to the Oda clan, instead of supporting Hongan-ji Temple which had lost its influence, and the anti-Oda group who was opposed to it, then Magoichi SUZUKI killed the head of the Tsuchihashi clan in 1582, the Suzuki clan gripped the leadership of Saigashu.

sen.j: しかし、同年に本能寺の変が起って信長が死んだため、後ろ盾を失った孫一は雑賀を逃亡し、豊臣秀吉を頼る。
sen.e: However, in the same year (1582) Nobunaga was killed in the Honnoji Incident, and Magoichi, who lost his backing, had to flee from Saiga, seeking refuge with Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI.

sen.e: Several soldiers' name capped by the surname 'Suzuki,' including the name of Magoichi, can be found as heads of the artillery of the Toyotomi clan in the records of a series of battles in which Hideyoshi took place, from the Battle of Komaki and Nagakute to the Bunroku-Keicho War.

sen.j: 重朝は1600年に関ヶ原の戦いの前哨戦である伏見城の攻略戦に石田三成方として参戦し、城将の鳥居元忠を討ち取る戦功をあげた。
sen.e: Shigetomo took part in the side of Mitsunari ISHIDA in the battle to capture Fushimi-jo Castle, which was a preliminary skirmish of the Battle of Sekigahara, and he achieved a merit of defeating the castle commander, Mototada TORII.

sen.e: The family ancestor, Shigeyoshi SUZUKI was a relative of Shigeie SUZUKI, and it is said that he was settled in Yanami, Mikawa Province (Yanami-cho, Toyota City, Aichi Prefecture) during the Kamakura Period or the Period of Northern and Southern Courts.

sen.j: 室町時代に矢並を本拠として加茂郡 (三河国)一帯に勢力を広げて三河西北部における有力国人として台頭し、戦国時代 (日本)には、寺部（豊田市寺部町）、酒呑（豊田市幸海町）、足助（豊田市足助町）、則定（豊田市足助町大字則定）などの諸家に分かれていた。
sen.e: During the Muromachi Period, the clan emerged as a powerful kokujin (local samurai) in the northwestern Mikawa, by extending its influence over Kamo Country (Mikawa Province) with its home base in Yanami, but in the Sengoku Period (period of warring states), the clan was divided into several branch families such as Terabe (Terabe-cho, Toyota City), Sachinomi (Kokai-cho, Toyota City), Asuke (Asuke-cho, Toyota City) and Norisada (Oaza Norisada, Asuke-cho, Toyoda City).

sen.e: After the Battle of Okehazama that broke out in 1560, the Suzuki clan served the Imagawa clan, but in 1564, the Asuke-jo Castle of Asuke Suzuki clan was attacked by Ieyasu, who gained independence from the Imagawa clan, and the Terabe Suzuki clan was attacked by Nobumori SAKUMA, the military commander of Oda clan in 1566, and both of them were downfallen.
